instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01958: What is 820-01958? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.CD3217: What is CD3217? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_G3H_RTC: What is 3V3_G3H_RTC? 3V3_G3H_RTC Is an abbreviation of PP3V3_G3H_RTC which is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Pulsing on <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Board is out
Board is stuck at 5v, it seems to draw amps .3 or less
I have pulsing on <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> which I found when trying to inspect the boot up process of the <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> chip. 
The board did have some significant liquid damage in the <RESISTOR>R3091</RESISTOR> and top right of <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>.
When plugged in to power, my thermal cam shows the bottom left corner of the <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> chip, then it looks like it shoots power (from the heat) to L7810.
I have had to run jumper wires because of the significant liquid damage noted above. 
Not finding any shorts.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Pulsing on <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Also, how do I renew my membership upgrade? My CC expired and when i try to cancel my membership since there is no other option, it wont let me cancel the memberships since it says "Your membership may have been cancelled already."

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Pulsing on <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
USB-meter restarts, or stuck in 0.3A?
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> pulsing too?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Pulsing on <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Meter never restarts, and is not stuck on .3 amps. When I first plug in the USB meter draws no amps, but after about 30-40 seconds, the amps jump to .39, for about 3 seconds, then the amps drop back to 0, and it repeats this cycle, the meter never reboots, but stays on 5v.
  <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>  goes from 12.3 to 11.3, so looks to be pulsing.
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> is not pulsing at all. At a solid 3.2v

Just noticed <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> pin 1 and 8 is erratic pulsing all over.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Pulsing on <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Probably more components damaged by corrosion.
Did you change <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>?
Be sure all resistors from page 23 are good, as traces too.

Try reflashing <CHIP>U3060</CHIP>.
Don't forget to make backup first...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Pulsing on <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I have swapped out both the <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> chips, no difference. These resistors are part of the problem. Let me upload a picture. The schematics I have do not show where all these circular pads are going to except for the closest one by <CAPACITOR>C3011</CAPACITOR> at the top right of this cap. What do you mean by flashing <CHIP>U3060</CHIP>? Reflow? When I replaced <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>, to two capacitors (<CAPACITOR>C3202</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C3102</CAPACITOR>) now appears to be reading at 405 wheras before they were reading in the low 100's. I have jumper wires as you see running to the same circuits. Still no change. I am stumped.
[ATTACH type="full"]60987[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Pulsing on <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"What do you mean by flashing <CHIP>U3060</CHIP>? Reflow?"
Loading new dump...
[URL unfurl="true"]https://drive.google.com/file/d/1mwLxROsu4zKkPn5elRLd_aqL-9wIaM-H/view?usp=share_link[/URL]

Did you check if all pads of that <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> chip have continuity to surrounding components?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Pulsing on <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Continuity looks good from what I could tell. I have a donor board here so I have been comparing in diode mode too.
As for <CHIP>U3060</CHIP>, I have a CH341A USB programmer here: [URL]https://www.aliexpress.us/item/3256801450125128.html?spm=a2g0o.order_list.order_list_main.5.3ea41802TlxcJ8&gatewayAdapt=glo2usa4itemAdapt&_randl_shipto=US[/URL]
I do not believe I have something small enough that this will connect to. Could you recommend something?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Pulsing on <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
You need USON-8 to DIP-8 adapter.
[URL unfurl="true"]https://www.ebay.ca/itm/165130189149[/URL]
[URL unfurl="true"]https://www.pcbway.com/project/shareproject/Universal_SPI_Flash_Adapter_WSON_SOP_WSON_USON_472d00c0.html[/URL]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Pulsing on <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Thanks, I have ordered these and am currently waiting on them to arrive.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Pulsing on <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Okay, I got the parts in today and I have been fussing with it all day long. I have used multiple software programmers but one of them told me the chip may be write protected and to click unprotect. I have tried this but get no where. It reads the chip just fine, but I cannot erase or reprogram the chip. What am I doing wrong?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Pulsing on <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Try to use another chip, from scrap board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Pulsing on <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Thanks, I used another chip from a donor board and I am having success, but I am trying to use the .bin file you provided but it tells me it successfully programmed the chip, but when I close out the program and reaqd the chip again, the chip goes back to what it had before. I also clicked verify and it is not matching up. See image below.[ATTACH type="full"]61007[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Pulsing on <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Well, 1/3 different programmers (software) worked I believe. I used the NeoProgrammer and even though it did not have the exact chip. I chose the one closest to W25Q80DV. Now to see if this helped.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Pulsing on <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="prodigy83, post: 96881, member: 32178"]
Now to see if this helped.
[/QUOTE]
The board is now at 5v but never pulls amps until after about 30 or so seconds, but then the USB-C meter reboots at random with both sides. Could this be because of the programming issues I have had? I know usually if it reboots like this, the <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> chip may need to be reflowed/replaced. This was my first programming of the SPI chip so I am unfamiliar with this process.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Pulsing on <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
You must be sure that TBT ROM was successfully programmed.

I suppose you have more damage caused by corrosion.
Severe liquid spill can affect T2, or CPU data lines.
